children.definition: Absolute dollar amount cap for the general disposition basket. Range: $1M to $20M+ depending on deal size. LMM: $1-3M, CMM: $3-8M, UMM: $10-20M.
children.name: Fixed Dollar Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 79 (a. Indebtedness)

children.definition: Cap expressed as percentage of LTM Consolidated EBITDA. Range: 5-15% of EBITDA. Often the 'greater of' alternative to the fixed dollar cap.
children.name: EBITDA Percentage Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: Cap expressed as 'the greater of' fixed dollar amount and percentage of EBITDA, allowing the basket to grow as the borrower's EBITDA increases. Standard in UMM/BSL deals.
children.name: Grower Formulation
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 89 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Investments in non-Loan Parties)

children.definition: Maximum aggregate amount of dispositions permitted under the general basket. May be expressed as a fixed dollar amount, a percentage of EBITDA, or a 'greater of' formulation combining both (grower basket).
children.name: Cap Amount
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket)

children.definition: Cap resets each fiscal year, providing recurring disposition capacity.
children.name: Annual Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket); Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: Cap applies on a cumulative basis from the closing date with no reset.
children.name: Aggregate Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket)

children.definition: Whether the cap is measured on an annual or aggregate (life-of-deal) basis. Annual caps reset each fiscal year; aggregate caps deplete permanently.
children.name: Measurement Period
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); Review Template Row 43 (Asset Sale Sweep – Reinvestment)

children.definition: Condition requiring no default or event of default for the general basket to be available. Typically a full EoD blocker (both payment and non-payment). Some aggressive deals have no EoD blocker or only a payment default blocker.
children.name: Default / EoD Blocker
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions); Review Template Row 98 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – General Basket); Review Template Row 118 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount)

children.definition: Whether the general basket requires fair market value and/or minimum cash consideration. Unlike the 75% basket, the general basket typically does NOT require cash consideration, making it a key flexibility tool.
children.name: FMV and Cash Conditions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Capped dollar or percentage-of-EBITDA basket permitting asset sales without the full conditions of the 75% cash consideration basket. Per DLS Preferred row 83 alt: 'general dollar basket' as one of the other asset sale baskets. Per PC Term Comparison: basket ranges for negative covenants are 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR max out at 40-50%; CMM/LMM in 10-25/30% range.' Typically subject to no default/EoD conditions.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: General Disposition Basket

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 83 alt: 'general dollar basket.' PC Term Comparison: 'UMM/BSLR 40-50%

children.definition: The specific financial ratio that must be satisfied pro forma after giving effect to the disposition. Commonly Total Net Leverage Ratio, but may be Secured Net Leverage Ratio or First Lien Net Leverage Ratio.
children.name: Applicable Financial Ratio
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 73 (b. Covenant)

children.definition: The ratio threshold that must be met pro forma for the disposition to be permitted. May be the incurrence covenant level or a step-down from closing. Typically 0.25x-0.50x inside the financial covenant level.
children.name: Required Ratio Level
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: How the pro forma calculation is performed: whether it gives effect to the disposition, the application of net proceeds, and any simultaneous transactions. May reference Limited Condition Transaction (LCT) election mechanics.
children.name: Pro Forma Methodology
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (Accordion); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: Whether the ratio basket is unlimited (uncapped if ratio is met) or has an additional dollar cap layered on top of the ratio condition. Most ratio baskets are uncapped -- the ratio itself serves as the constraint.
children.name: Uncapped or Capped
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 91 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Investments in Unsubs/JVs); Review Template Row 123 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Other)

children.definition: Disposition basket permitting unlimited or higher-cap asset sales subject to pro forma compliance with a specified financial ratio. Per PC Term Comparison: 'Reject unlimited leveraged based asset sale basket.' Per DLS Preferred: not included in preferred position. More common in BSL and UMM deals where leverage step-down creates earned flexibility. Bank position is strongly opposed to ratio-tested unlimited disposition baskets.

DISP_GENERAL_BASKET.label: Dispositions - General Basket
exactPhrases: greater of $[X] and [Y]% of LTM EBITDA
in an aggregate amount not to exceed
greater of $[X] and [Y]% of LTM EBITDA
in an aggregate amount not to exceed

children.name: Ratio Disposition Basket

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Ratio Basket

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison: 'Reject unlimited leveraged based asset sale basket.' DLS Preferred row 83: not included in preferred position.

children.definition: Standard FMV determination by the board of directors (or a responsible officer) in good faith. The most common mechanism. 'Good faith' standard provides borrower discretion while requiring procedural fairness.
children.name: Board Determination

red_flags.text: No FMV requirement on asset sales -- permits dispositions at below-market value, enabling value transfer to affiliates or sponsors

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios)

children.definition: Dollar threshold above which an independent third-party appraisal is required to confirm fair market value. When present, typically triggered at $10-50M per transaction or 10-25% of EBITDA. Not universally required.
children.name: Independent Appraisal Threshold
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold); Review Template Row 99 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold)

children.definition: Requirement that the disposition be conducted on arm's length terms, ensuring no related-party discount. May overlap with the affiliate transactions covenant for transfers to affiliates.
children.name: Arm's Length Requirement

red_flags.text: No FMV requirement on asset sales -- permits dispositions at below-market value, enabling value transfer to affiliates or sponsors

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 124 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates –); Review Template Row 125 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – De Minimis Threshold); Review Template Row 126 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – Sponsor Management Fees)

children.definition: Universal requirement that asset dispositions be made at not less than fair market value. Per DLS Preferred row 83(i): 'fair market value' is the first condition for permitted non-ordinary course asset sales. Per Learning Material: 'Borrower must receive fair market value consideration.' FMV is typically determined by the board of directors in good faith. Universal prevalence across the corpus.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=easy vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Fair Market Value Requirement

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

red_flags.text: No FMV requirement on asset sales -- permits dispositions at below-market value, enabling value transfer to affiliates or sponsors

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 83(i): 'fair market value.' Learning Material Section (3): 'Borrower must receive fair market value consideration.'

children.definition: Standard requirement that at least 75% of the total consideration received in a permitted asset disposition consist of cash or cash equivalents. This threshold ensures the borrower realizes liquid value from asset sales rather than accepting illiquid consideration that cannot be applied to mandatory prepayments or reinvested in productive replacement assets.
children.name: Standard 75%

children.definition: Alternative lower threshold of 50% cash, typically paired with removal of reinvestment rights, creating a trade-off between consideration quality and reinvestment flexibility.
children.name: Alternative 50%

children.definition: The minimum percentage of total consideration that must be in cash or cash equivalents. Standard: 75%. Some deals use 50% with compensating restrictions (e.g., no reinvestment rights at the lower threshold, as seen in Geneva).
children.name: Cash Percentage Standard
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions)

children.definition: Physical cash, wire transfers, and instruments qualifying as 'Cash Equivalents' per the credit agreement definitions.
children.name: Actual Cash / Cash Equivalents
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Indebtedness of the borrower or subsidiary assumed by the transferee, provided it is not subordinated or intercompany. Release from the obligation is treated as cash receipt.
children.name: Debt Assumed by Transferee
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 64 (Negative Covenants – General)

children.definition: Notes or obligations received that are convertible to cash within 180 days (or similar period) of receipt.
children.name: Convertible Obligations
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); Review Template Row 81 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Sale-Leaseback debt)

children.definition: Non-cash consideration (e.g., equity, promissory notes) designated as cash equivalents up to a cap. Cap typically $1-5M or 5-20% EBITDA in LMM/CMM; up to $225M / 50% EBITDA in aggressive UMM deals (Geneva). When converted to actual cash, the cap refreshes.
children.name: Designated Non-Cash Consideration
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: What qualifies as 'cash or cash equivalents' for the consideration test. Standard inclusions: (i) actual cash/cash equivalents, (ii) assumption of debt by transferee (not subordinated or intercompany), (iii) obligations convertible to cash within 180 days, (iv) designated non-cash consideration up to cap.
children.name: Cash Equivalents Definition
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Absolute dollar cap on outstanding designated non-cash consideration.
children.name: Fixed Dollar Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 79 (a. Indebtedness)

children.definition: Cap expressed as percentage of Consolidated EBITDA, often in a 'greater of' with fixed dollar.
children.name: EBITDA Percentage Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: How the cap is restored: when non-cash consideration is converted to actual cash, the cap refreshes by the amount of the conversion, allowing new designations.
children.name: Refresh Mechanics
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 64 (Negative Covenants – General)

children.definition: Maximum amount of designated non-cash consideration that may count toward the cash consideration test at any time outstanding. Key sizing parameter: LMM 5% EBITDA, CMM 5-10% EBITDA, UMM 10-50% EBITDA. Cap refreshes as non-cash is converted to cash.
children.name: Designated Non-Cash Consideration Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: 75% test measured on aggregate basis from closing date. Prevents transaction fragmentation. Bank preferred.
children.name: Cumulative from Closing
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold); Review Template Row 96 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions); Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket)

children.definition: 75% test measured independently for each disposition. More borrower-friendly; allows some transactions to fall below 75%.
children.name: Per Transaction
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 33 (Alternate transaction fee)

children.definition: Whether the 75% cash consideration test is applied per-transaction or on a cumulative basis from the closing date. Cumulative is preferred by private credit (prevents fragmentation gaming); per-transaction is more borrower-friendly.
children.name: Measurement Basis
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); Review Template Row 96 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions)

children.definition: Dollar or EBITDA percentage below which individual transactions are exempt from the 75% test.
children.name: Per-Transaction Amount
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket); Review Template Row 128 (Limited Conditionality Transactions)

children.definition: Annual aggregate dollar amount below which the 75% test is not triggered. Some deals use both per-transaction and annual thresholds.
children.name: Per-Fiscal-Year Amount
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions)

children.definition: Dollar or EBITDA-percentage threshold below which the 75% cash consideration test does not apply. Typical: 5-15% of EBITDA per transaction. LMM: 5-7% EBITDA, CMM: 7-10%, UMM: 10-15%. Key lever: higher threshold delays when the test kicks in.
children.name: Threshold-Based Trigger
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold); Review Template Row 44 (Asset Sale Sweep – Stepdowns)

children.definition: Requirements governing the form of consideration in asset dispositions. The 75% cash consideration test: at least 75% of total consideration must be cash or cash equivalents. Per Learning Material: certain non-cash consideration is deemed cash: (i) non-subordinated liabilities assumed by the transferee, (ii) obligations convertible to cash within 180 days, (iii) designated non-cash consideration up to a specified cap. PC Term Comparison threshold: 5-10% of EBITDA for UMM/BSLR, no threshold or max 5% for CMM/LMM.

DISP_CASH_CONSIDERATION.label: Dispositions - 75% Cash Consideration
semanticVariants: cash consideration requirement for asset sales
fair market value requirement for dispositions
cash consideration requirement for asset sales
fair market value requirement for dispositions

children.name: Consideration Requirements

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket

children.definition_source: Learning Material Section (3): 'At least 75% of consideration must be cash. Certain non-cash consideration is deemed cash.' PC Term Comparison: '75% Threshold: UMM/BSLR 5-10% of EBITDA

children.definition: All net cash proceeds must be applied to mandatory prepayment. Standard in private credit.
children.name: Fixed 100%
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: Sweep percentage decreases as leverage improves. E.g., 100% above 3.5x, 50% between 2.5-3.5x, 0% below 2.5x. Standard in BSL, rare in PC.
children.name: Leverage-Based Step-Down
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 41 (d. Maximum leverage)

children.definition: Percentage of net cash proceeds that must be applied to mandatory prepayment. Near-universal 100% in private credit. BSL may have leverage-based step-downs (100% -> 50% -> 0% as leverage decreases). Stepdowns extremely rare in PC (1-2 deals).
children.name: Sweep Percentage

red_flags.text: Asset sale sweep below 100% in Term Loan B -- allows borrower to retain portion of asset sale proceeds without reinvestment obligation

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: Reasonable out-of-pocket costs, fees, commissions, and expenses incurred in connection with the disposition.
children.name: Transaction Costs Deduction
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket)

children.definition: Income, transfer, and other taxes payable or estimated to be payable as a result of the disposition.
children.name: Tax Deduction

children.definition: Prepayment of indebtedness secured by a lien on the disposed asset that has priority over the credit facility lien.
children.name: Prior Lien Payoff
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 58 (u. Other conditions); Review Template Row 25 (Incremental Amount – prepayments)

children.definition: Deductions from gross disposition proceeds for reasonable reserves established against indemnification obligations, post-closing purchase price adjustments, and other contingent liabilities related to the asset sale. Reduces the net proceeds subject to mandatory prepayment, recognizing that the borrower must retain funds to cover potential seller obligations under the disposition agreement.
children.name: Reserves

children.definition: How net cash proceeds are calculated from gross disposition proceeds. Deductions include: (i) transaction costs and fees, (ii) taxes payable, (iii) prepayment of indebtedness secured by the sold assets (prior liens). The calculation determines the amount subject to the sweep.
children.name: Net Cash Proceeds Calculation
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Which disposition baskets trigger the mandatory prepayment sweep. Standard scope: 75% cash consideration basket, sale-leasebacks, and casualty/condemnation events. The general basket may or may not trigger the sweep depending on the deal.
children.name: Sweep Trigger Baskets
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: Order of application of asset sale sweep proceeds across facilities. Typically: first to term loans (pro rata or as directed by the administrative agent), then to revolving commitments. May include offer to term loan lenders with declined amounts going to the borrower.
children.name: Prepayment Waterfall
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage)

children.definition: Mechanism governing how net cash proceeds from dispositions must be applied: mandatory prepayment of term loans, reinvestment in the business, or (if retained due to leverage step-downs or lender declination) addition to the builder basket. Per Learning Material: 'The portion not required to be swept is added to the Builder Basket, which is available for restricted payments, restricted debt payments and investments.' Net cash proceeds = gross proceeds minus transaction costs, taxes, prior lien payoff, and indemnification reserves.
children.name: Proceeds Application

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

children.definition_source: Learning Material Section (1)-(4): mandatory prepayment + reinvestment + builder basket + declined proceeds. DLS Preferred row 70: 'proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep.'

children.definition: 365-day / 12-month reinvestment period. The most common standard in the private credit market.
children.name: 12 Month Period (Standard)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 48 (k. Pro Forma Financial Statements); Review Template Row 43 (Asset Sale Sweep – Reinvestment)

children.definition: 18-month reinvestment period. Borrower-friendly, seen in UMM and aggressive sponsor deals.
children.name: 18 Month Period (Extended)

red_flags.text: Reinvestment period exceeds 18 months (including commitment extension) -- delays mandatory prepayment and reduces lender protection from asset sales

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 48 (k. Pro Forma Financial Statements); Review Template Row 43 (Asset Sale Sweep – Reinvestment)

children.definition: Base period (from receipt of proceeds) during which borrower may reinvest. Standard: 365 days. Range: 270-540 days. DLS preferred: 360 days. UMM/BSL aggressive: 450-540 days.
children.name: Initial Reinvestment Period
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: 180-day / 6-month extension for binding commitments. Market standard.
children.name: 6 Month Extension (Standard)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Extension permits letters of intent (not just binding commitments) to qualify. More borrower-friendly; criticized by lenders as too loose.
children.name: LOI Accepted

children.definition: Additional period (beyond the initial period) during which proceeds may be applied to a binding commitment entered into during the initial period. Standard: 180 days (6 months). Some deals accept letters of intent (LOI) in addition to binding commitments.
children.name: Binding Commitment Extension
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Definition of what constitutes a permitted reinvestment target. Typically 'assets useful in the business' of the borrower or its restricted subsidiaries. Key: should exclude reinvestment in unrestricted subs or non-guarantors without Investment covenant compliance.
children.name: Useful Asset Restriction
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions)

children.definition: Whether reinvestment rights survive during an event of default. If no EoD blocker, borrower can continue reinvesting even while in default. Sponsor push point; lenders prefer reinvestment to require no EoD.
children.name: No EoD Blocker on Reinvestment
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 43 (Asset Sale Sweep – Reinvestment)

children.definition: Time period during which the borrower may reinvest asset sale proceeds instead of making mandatory prepayment. Per DLS Preferred: 'reinvest or commit to reinvest within [6/12] months with [90/180]-day extension.' Per PC Term Comparison: Aggressive UMM/BSLR at 450/540 days plus 180; otherwise 360 plus 180. Per Learning Material: 'Borrower is given ~18 months. If committed within that period, extended by an additional 6 months.' Tighter deals require investment in fixed/capital assets, not operating expenses.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Reinvestment Period

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

red_flags.text: Reinvestment period exceeds 18 months (including commitment extension) -- delays mandatory prepayment and reduces lender protection from asset sales

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70: 'reinvest within [6/12] months with [90/180]-day extension.' PC Term Comparison: 'Reinvestment: UMM/BSLR 450/540 + 180. Otherwise 360 + 180.' Learning Material: 'Borrower is given ~18 months plus 6 months if committed.'

children.definition: Sales of inventory, products, and services in the ordinary course of business. Universal exclusion. The borrower's core commercial activity is not constrained by the dispositions covenant.
children.name: Ordinary Course Inventory
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Dispositions of obsolete, worn-out, damaged, or surplus equipment and property no longer useful in the business. Universal exclusion. Prevents the covenant from blocking routine asset management.
children.name: Obsolete or Worn-Out Equipment
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Granting of leases, subleases, licenses, and sublicenses in the ordinary course of business. Key distinction: non-exclusive licenses are generally excluded; exclusive licenses may constitute effective dispositions (see IP licensing concept).
children.name: Leases and Non-Exclusive Licenses
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions)

children.definition: Abandonment or non-renewal of intellectual property rights that are no longer economically desirable or commercially reasonable. Typically requires a good-faith determination that the IP is not material to the business.
children.name: IP Abandonment

children.definition: Dispositions in connection with corporate reorganizations, consolidations, or tax planning among the borrower and restricted subsidiaries, provided the collateral and guarantee structure is maintained.
children.name: Intercompany Restructuring

children.definition: Exclusion for dispositions of obsolete, worn-out, or surplus property no longer useful in the ordinary course of business. A universal carveout recognizing that asset turnover of depreciated or non-functional equipment should not consume disposition basket capacity.
children.name: Obsolete Worn Out
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Exclusion for collection of accounts receivable in the ordinary course of business. Ensures that routine trade receivable collections and factoring of overdue accounts are not captured by the disposition covenant's consent or proceeds sweep requirements.
children.name: Receivables Collection

children.definition: Exclusion for transfers of cash and cash equivalents, including money market instruments and short-term government securities. Recognizes that ordinary treasury management activities and cash movements should not trigger disposition covenant restrictions.
children.name: Cash And Ce
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions)

children.definition: Categories of asset sales excluded from the dispositions covenant entirely -- not counted against any basket. Per Learning Material, customary exclusions: (1) inventory and goods in ordinary course, (2) non-exclusive licenses/leases, (3) outdated, obsolete, surplus property. Also: intragroup dispositions, receivables collection, IP abandonment, and transfers of cash/cash equivalents.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=easy vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Excluded Dispositions

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold

children.definition_source: Learning Material Section (3)(1)-(2): 'Dispositions of inventory in ordinary course. Licenses and leases not materially interfering. Dispositions of outdated, obsolete, surplus property. Dispositions between borrower and restricted subsidiaries without limit.'

children.definition: Transfers between loan parties (borrower and guarantor subsidiaries). Typically unrestricted since both entities are within the credit group. No investment covenant compliance required.
children.name: Loan Party to Loan Party
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 30 (Term Loan)

children.definition: Transfers to non-loan parties are permitted but subject to an aggregate dollar or EBITDA-percentage cap.
children.name: Dollar-Capped
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold); Review Template Row 81 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Sale-Leaseback debt)

children.definition: Transfers to non-loan parties deemed an investment under the Investment covenant, requiring compliance with permitted investment baskets. Cross-covenant governance.
children.name: Treated as Investment
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments); Review Template Row 89 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Investments in non-Loan Parties); Review Template Row 100 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – Sale-Leaseback)

children.definition: Transfers from a loan party to a non-guarantor restricted subsidiary. Typically capped or treated as an investment requiring Investment covenant compliance. Key protective mechanism against asset stripping out of the credit group.
children.name: Loan Party to Non-Loan Party
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security)

children.definition: Transfers from non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries to loan parties. Generally unrestricted as they move assets INTO the credit group, improving lender protection.
children.name: Non-Loan Party to Loan Party
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security)

DISP_NON_LOAN_PARTY.label: Dispositions - Non-Loan Party Sales
exactPhrases: sales to Restricted Subsidiaries that are not Loan Parties
semanticVariants: sales to restricted subs that are not guarantors

exactPhrases: sales to Restricted Subsidiaries that are not Loan Parties
semanticVariants: sales to restricted subs that are not guarantors

children.definition: Asset transfers between the borrower and its restricted subsidiaries. Per Learning Material: 'Dispositions between or among the borrower and one or more restricted subsidiaries are permitted without limit. If the credit agreement restricts investments in non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries, consider whether dispositions to such restricted subsidiaries should be subject to additional restrictions.' Per Learning Material: 'Watch out for language that would permit unlimited dispositions to unrestricted subsidiaries or to Holdings.'

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Intercompany Transfers
children.definition_source: Learning Material Section (2): 'Dispositions between borrower and restricted subsidiaries permitted without limit. Watch for unlimited dispositions to unrestricted subs or Holdings.'

children.definition: Dollar cap applies per fiscal year, refreshing annually. Standard in conservative deals.
children.name: Capped Per Fiscal Year
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions)

children.definition: Dollar cap on total sale-leasebacks over life of deal. More restrictive than annual.
children.name: Capped Aggregate

children.definition: No dollar limitation on sale-leaseback transactions. Aggressive; creates unlimited off-balance-sheet leverage risk.
children.name: Uncapped
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 91 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Investments in Unsubs/JVs); Review Template Row 123 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Other)

children.definition: Whether sale-leasebacks are capped (by dollar amount or period) or uncapped. Conservative: capped per fiscal year with full conditions. Aggressive: uncapped. PC Term Comparison: UMM/BSL often uncapped.
children.name: Cap Structure
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket)

children.definition: Applicable to permitted sale-leasebacks: arm's length terms, fair market value, minimum cash consideration (typically 90%), and compliance with mandatory prepayment provisions.
children.name: Conditions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 58 (Other conditions)

children.definition: Interaction with other covenants: the lease created by a sale-leaseback is indebtedness under the capital lease basket; the disposition must comply with the dispositions covenant; the lien on the leased asset must comply with the liens covenant.
children.name: Cross-Covenant Compliance

children.definition: Permission for the borrower to sell assets and simultaneously lease them back from the purchaser. Per DLS Preferred row 83 alt: 'sale and leaseback transactions' listed as a separate disposition basket. Per PC Term Comparison: 'Sale-leaseback debt: Aggressive UMM/BSLR: Often uncapped. Otherwise: capped.' Creates off-balance-sheet financing. Sale-leasebacks may trigger the asset sale sweep per DLS Preferred row 70: mandatory prepayment includes 'sale leaseback transactions.'

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Sale-Leaseback Transactions

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 83 alt: sale-leaseback as separate basket. DLS row 70: 'including sale leaseback transactions.' PC Term Comparison: 'Sale-leaseback: Aggressive UMM/BSLR uncapped

children.definition: De minimis threshold for the combined asset sale + casualty sweep, typically 10% of EBITDA per fiscal year or per event. Proceeds below the deductible are not subject to mandatory prepayment.
children.name: Combined Deductible

children.definition: Whether the standard reinvestment period applies to casualty/condemnation proceeds. Standard: yes, same reinvestment rights as voluntary dispositions. Conservative: shorter reinvestment period for casualty events.
children.name: Reinvestment Rights Apply
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 43 (Asset Sale Sweep – Reinvestment)

children.definition: Definition of which insurance proceeds are captured: property damage, business interruption, title insurance, environmental insurance. Business interruption proceeds are sometimes excluded from the sweep.
children.name: Insurance Proceeds Scope
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants)

children.definition: Treatment of insurance proceeds from casualty events and condemnation awards. Per DLS Preferred row 70: '100% of net cash proceeds from all non-ordinary course asset sales and insurance/condemnation proceeds.' Per Intro Guide: asset sale sweep provisions 'also pick up proceeds from casualty or recovery events (insurance proceeds or condemnation awards). This could be included within the asset sale sweep or in a separate section.' Typically treated as involuntary dispositions with the same reinvestment rights.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Casualty and Condemnation Events
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70: 'insurance/condemnation proceeds.' Intro Guide: 'asset sale sweep also picks up casualty/recovery events.'

children.definition: Requirement that the assets received have a fair market value at least equal to the assets transferred. Determination by board in good faith.
children.name: FMV Equivalence

children.definition: Received assets must be useful in the same or a similar line of business as the borrower and its restricted subsidiaries. Prevents swaps into non-core assets.
children.name: Useful in the Business
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 44 (Business MAC)

children.definition: Cash component permitted in an otherwise like-kind asset exchange (swap) transaction. When asset swaps include a cash equalization payment, the cash portion is treated as disposition proceeds subject to the mandatory prepayment waterfall, while the non-cash (asset) portion constitutes a permitted reinvestment in replacement assets.
children.name: Cash Boot
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions)

children.definition: Exchange of assets for other assets of comparable or greater fair market value useful in the business. Per Learning Material: 'Exchange of assets for other assets useful for the borrowers business. Note that the asset swap basket is often unlimited in indentures.' Per DLS Preferred row 83 alt(iv): 'asset swaps' listed as a separate disposition basket. Exempt from the cash consideration test and often from the asset sale sweep.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Permitted Asset Swaps

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

children.definition_source: Learning Material: 'asset swap basket often unlimited in indentures.' DLS Preferred row 83 alt(iv): 'asset swaps.'

children.definition: Threshold below which the dispositions covenant does not apply at all. Typically $1-5M per transaction. Dispositions below this threshold need not satisfy any basket, FMV, or cash consideration conditions.
children.name: Covenant-Level Threshold
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold); Review Template Row 99 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold)

children.definition: Separate threshold below which the asset sale sweep is not triggered, even if the disposition is otherwise subject to the covenant. Creates 'double de minimis' risk when combined with the covenant-level threshold.
children.name: Sweep-Level Threshold
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: Risk flag: when both the disposition covenant and the asset sale sweep have independent de minimis thresholds, a single sale could be exempt from both at up to 2x the threshold amount. Review Template warns explicitly against this.
children.name: Double De Minimis Risk
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold); Review Template Row 67 (Unrestricted Subsidiaries - generally); Review Template Row 99 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold)

children.definition: Dollar threshold below which individual dispositions are exempt from the covenant entirely or from specific conditions. Per Learning Material: 'Exclusion from provision for de minimis transactions. Prepayment is required if aggregate amount of net cash proceeds per transaction or during a fiscal year exceeds a threshold. Check that there isnt a double de minimis exclusion (in the definition of disposition or elsewhere).' Per PC Term Comparison: 'Raise De Minimis threshold with client. Aggressive UMM/BSLR: 5-10% of EBITDA. Otherwise: 2.5-5% or none.'

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=easy vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: De Minimis Threshold

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

red_flags.text: Disposition covenant de minimis threshold and mandatory prepayment trigger threshold are misaligned -- creates gap for prepayment-free sales

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold
Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Threshold
Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – De Minimis Threshold

children.definition_source: Learning Material: 'de minimis transactions, check for double de minimis.' PC Term Comparison: 'De Minimis: Aggressive UMM/BSLR 5-10% EBITDA

children.definition: Requirement that no default or event of default exists or would result from the disposition. May be a full EoD blocker (both payment and non-payment) or a limited default blocker (only specified defaults).
children.name: No Default Requirement
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 10

children.definition: Requirement that the borrower deliver a compliance certificate to the administrative agent in connection with a permitted asset disposition, certifying pro forma covenant compliance and satisfaction of all conditions to the disposition. Provides the lender syndicate with documentary evidence that the transaction meets covenant requirements before closing.
children.name: Compliance Certificate
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 4

children.definition: Obligation to provide advance written notice to the administrative agent before consummating a permitted asset disposition, specifying the assets being sold, the consideration, and the intended application of proceeds. Notice periods typically range from 5 to 30 business days, giving lenders visibility into material asset sales and time to assess covenant compliance.
children.name: Notice Requirement

children.definition: Conditions that must be satisfied for dispositions under various baskets. Per DLS Preferred row 83: 'no default or event of default is continuing' is condition (iv). Per PC Term Comparison: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: payment/bktcy EoD or no stopper; Otherwise: full EoD.' Additional conditions include compliance certificates and notice requirements. The depth and breadth of conditions vary significantly by segment and deal aggressiveness.
dls_ref: DLS:11:Conditions to incurrence: Bring down of

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=easy vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: General Conditions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 83(iv): 'no default or event of default is continuing.' PC Term Comparison: 'Aggressive UMM/BSLR: payment/bktcy EoD or no stopper

children.definition: When unused reinvestment proceeds become 'excess proceeds' and trigger mandatory prepayment. Standard: at the end of the reinvestment period (including any commitment extension). Business day grace period (typically 5 days).
children.name: Mandatory Prepayment Trigger
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting); Review Template Row 25 (Incremental Amount – prepayments)

children.definition: Net cash proceeds retained by the borrower (due to deductible, leverage-based stepdown, lender declination, or non-sweepable portion) are added to the Available Amount builder basket. Key leakage vector: retained asset sale proceeds can fund restricted payments, investments, or debt prepayments.
children.name: Builder Basket Feed
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 3

children.definition: If the mandatory prepayment is structured as an offer to term lenders, lenders may decline their pro rata share. Declined amounts typically revert to the borrower and may be added to the Available Amount. Creates another leakage path.
children.name: Lender Declination
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 60 (Lender Selection)

children.definition: Treatment of net cash proceeds that exceed reinvestment capacity or are not reinvested within the reinvestment period. Per Learning Material: 'The portion not required to be swept is added to the Builder Basket, which is available for restricted payments, restricted debt payments and investments.' Excess proceeds must be applied to mandatory prepayment. Per DLS Preferred row 70 alt: 'Step downs to 50% and 0% upon achievement of specified leverage ratios + retained asset sale proceeds build the available amount.'

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Excess Proceeds Treatment
children.definition_source: Learning Material: 'unswept portion added to Builder Basket.' DLS Preferred row 70 alt: 'retained asset sale proceeds build the Available Amount.'

children.definition: Direct feed from dispositions to the mandatory prepayment section (asset sale sweep). Net cash proceeds from qualifying dispositions must be applied to term loan prepayment. The primary deleveraging mechanism for asset sales.
children.name: Mandatory Prepayment Link
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Parallel mandatory prepayment mechanism. Both asset sale sweep and ECF sweep are mandatory prepayment triggers with deductibles and reinvestment/credit provisions. Retained amounts from both feed the builder basket.
children.name: ECF Sweep Interaction
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 45 (ECF Sweep – Holiday); Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: Retained asset sale proceeds (not swept) are added to the Available Amount builder basket, increasing RP/RDP/Investment capacity. HIGH risk: creates a counter-deleveraging incentive where asset sales fund distributions.
children.name: Available Amount Feed

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Ratio Test

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (Available Amount); KCT Cat 4 Item 3; Review Template Row 95 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Other); Review Template Row 118 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount); Review Template Row 119 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Starter); Review Template Row 122 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Ratio Test); Review Template Row 123 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Other)

children.definition: Dispositions of collateral trigger automatic lien release under the security documents. The administrative agent must release the lien on the disposed asset if the disposition is permitted under the credit agreement.
children.name: Lien Release Mechanics
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); Review Template Row 40 (Collateral/Guarantor release – Chewy); Review Template Row 64 (Negative Covenants – General)

children.definition: Intercompany dispositions to non-loan parties are treated as investments. Non-cash consideration received may constitute an investment. Reinvested proceeds may qualify as permitted investments. Multi-directional interaction.
children.name: Investment Covenant Link
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments)

children.definition: Prohibition on selling or transferring material IP to unrestricted subsidiaries. Must be paired with investment-side J.Crew blocker for complete protection. Exclusive licensing treated as effective transfer. 85% prevalence.
children.name: J.Crew Disposition Protection
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 69 (Negative Covenants – J Crew protection)

children.definition: Mechanical links between the dispositions covenant and other covenants. Per Learning Material: asset sale proceeds feed mandatory prepayment (the asset sale sweep); the portion not swept builds the Available Amount for RPs/Investments/RDPs; intercompany dispositions to non-loan parties interact with the investment covenant; and dispositions of collateral trigger automatic lien release. Per PC Term Comparison: 'J Crew protections standard' -- dispositions of material IP to unrestricted subs are blocked. These cross-references create cascade effects from a single disposition.
children.name: Cross-Covenant Links
children.definition_source: Learning Material: dispositions-to-mandatory-prepayment-to-builder-basket chain. PC Term Comparison: 'J Crew protections standard.' Intro Guide: cascade effects.
pc_ref: : 'J Crew protections standard.' Intro Guide: cascade effects.

children.definition: Outright prohibition on Delaware divisional mergers or similar statutory divisions in any jurisdiction. The most protective approach.
children.name: Division Prohibition

children.definition: Division treated as a disposition of the assets allocated to the new entity, subject to all dispositions covenant conditions (FMV, cash consideration, etc.).
children.name: Treated as Disposition
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 102 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – Other)

children.definition: Credit agreement is silent on Delaware divisions. Risk: borrower could argue a division is not a 'sale, transfer, or disposition' since no transfer of title occurs. Pre-2018 agreements are uniformly silent.
children.name: No Provision (Silent)

children.definition: Treatment of Delaware divisional mergers (statutory division under DLLCA Section 18-217) as dispositions. Per Learning Material: 'transfers of assets in connection with Delaware LLC divisions and similar transactions' are included in the broad Disposition definition. Post-2018 drafting innovation. Some CAs prohibit divisions entirely; others treat them as dispositions subject to the covenant.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=easy vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Delaware Divisions (Post-2018)

children.definition: Non-collateral dispositions may have relaxed conditions: no mandatory prepayment trigger, no cash consideration requirement, or higher thresholds.
children.name: Reduced Conditions
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 118 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount)

children.definition: Definition of 'non-collateral' assets: assets excluded from the collateral package by definition (e.g., foreign assets, immaterial subsidiaries, specific excluded assets listed in the security agreement).
children.name: Scope Definition

children.definition: Dispositions of non-collateral assets, subject to the dispositions negative covenant as a cash flow control. May have reduced conditions since these asset sales do not diminish the lender's security interest. Per Intro Guide: lenders rank asset location by preference -- Loan Party collateral first, non-collateral assets of restricted subs second. Proceeds may still be subject to mandatory prepayment depending on sweep scope definition.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=easy vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Non-Collateral Dispositions
children.definition_source: Intro Guide: asset location hierarchy (Loan Parties > Non-Guarantor Restricted Subs). DLS Preferred row 70: sweep scope may include non-collateral.

children.definition: Whether securitization transactions are capped or uncapped. Conservative: capped with dedicated basket. Aggressive: uncapped, all-asset permitted.
children.name: Cap Structure
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket)

children.definition: Whether all-asset securitizations are permitted, allowing any asset class (including core operating assets) to be securitized. PC strongly disfavors; BSL may permit.
children.name: All-Asset Permitted
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions)

children.definition: Requirements to ring-fence securitized assets from the collateral pool, limit recourse to the borrower, and ensure proceeds interact with the mandatory prepayment mechanism.
children.name: Ring-Fencing Requirements
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold); Review Template Row 101 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – Securitizations)

children.definition: Permission for the borrower to transfer receivables to a securitization vehicle. Per DLS Preferred row 83 alt(v): 'sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities.' Per PC Term Comparison: 'Securitization Debt: Typically capped in all transactions. Avoid all asset securitizations.' Removes assets from the collateral pool but generates proceeds that may be subject to the mandatory prepayment framework.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Securitization Transactions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 83 alt(v): 'qualified receivables facilities.' PC Term Comparison: 'Securitization debt typically capped. Avoid all asset securitizations.'

children.definition: Whether the credit agreement explicitly treats exclusive IP licenses as dispositions subject to the covenant. Modern best practice includes this; older agreements may be silent.
children.name: Treatment as Disposition

children.definition: Exclusion for exclusive licenses granted in the ordinary course of business (e.g., technology licensing as a revenue stream). Prevents the covenant from blocking the borrower's core IP monetization strategy.
children.name: Ordinary Course Carve-Out
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Treatment of exclusive intellectual property licenses as effective dispositions. Per Learning Material: 'J. Crew protection includes an overriding provision in the dispositions covenant restricting dispositions of intellectual property material to the loan parties to unrestricted subsidiaries.' Per PC Term Comparison: 'get non-exclusive for licenses; try to block material IP transfers to non-guarantors if possible.' An exclusive license is functionally equivalent to an IP sale.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Exclusive IP Licensing
children.definition_source: Learning Material: J.Crew protection restricting IP dispositions to unrestricted subs. PC Term Comparison: 'get non-exclusive for licenses

children.definition: Requirement that transfers to non-guarantors comply with the Investment covenant as if the transfer were a new investment in the non-guarantor subsidiary.
children.name: Investment Covenant Compliance
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 1 Item 5; Review Template Row 88 (Negative Covenants – Investments)

children.definition: Some deals have a dedicated cap on transfers to non-guarantors, independent of the investment covenant baskets. Provides additional protection against asset migration out of the guarantor group.
children.name: Separate Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 89 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Investments in non-Loan Parties); Review Template Row 97 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – 75% Cash Consideration Basket)

children.definition: Dispositions that transfer assets from loan parties to non-guarantor restricted subsidiaries. Per PC Term Comparison: 'Cap dispositions to non-Loan Parties (shared with non-LP Investments and intercompany debt baskets).' Per Intro Guide: Tier 2 leakage -- assets move from entities with pledged assets to entities where lenders have only equity interest. Requires investment covenant compliance in most deals.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Dispositions to Non-Guarantor Restricted Subs

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap
Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Non-guarantor/foreign subsidiary debt
Negative Covenants – Dispositions – De Minimis Threshold

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison: 'Cap dispositions to non-Loan Parties (shared with non-LP Investments and intercompany debt baskets).' Intro Guide: Tier 2 leakage.
pc_ref: : 'Cap dispositions to non-Loan Parties (shared with non-LP Investments and intercompany debt baskets).' Intro Guide: Tier 2 leakage.

children.definition: How proceeds from unrestricted subsidiary equity sales are treated: whether they are subject to the asset sale sweep or are excluded. Excluded in some deals since the asset was already outside the restricted group.
children.name: Proceeds Treatment
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 83 (e. Dispositions); Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage)

children.definition: Interaction with unrestricted subsidiary redesignation mechanics: selling equity in an unrestricted sub vs. redesignating it as restricted produce different economic and covenant outcomes.
children.name: Redesignation Interaction

children.definition: Dispositions of equity interests in unrestricted subsidiaries. Per DLS Preferred row 92: preferred position is 'No ability to designate unrestricted subsidiaries.' Per PC Term Comparison: ability to dividend unrestricted subs is 'leakage and can be round tripped to build contribution debt or other RP capacity.' These assets sit outside the restricted group, so the disposition is of the borrower's investment in the unrestricted subsidiary.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Unrestricted Subsidiary Equity Dispositions

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Unrestricted Subsidiary Stock

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 92: 'No ability to designate unrestricted subsidiaries.' PC Term Comparison: 'dividend Unrestricted Subs is leakage, can be round tripped.'

children.definition: Dispositions of receivables in connection with factoring, receivables purchase facilities, or supply chain financing. May overlap with securitization basket but typically has separate treatment.
children.name: Receivables Financing

children.definition: Dispositions that are expressly permitted under other negative covenants (e.g., dispositions constituting permitted investments, restricted payments constituting dispositions). Prevents double-counting across covenants.
children.name: Cross-Reference to Other NegCovs
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 84 (Other); Review Template Row 146 (Cross-default); Review Template Row 156 (Other)

children.definition: Issuance of equity interests in subsidiaries to third parties, treated as a disposition of the subsidiary's equity. Subject to disposition covenant conditions.
children.name: Equity Issuance Treated as Disposition
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); Review Template Row 102 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions – Other)

children.definition: Disposition basket for buy-sell transactions in joint ventures, permitting partners to acquire or dispose of JV interests pursuant to contractual buy-sell, tag-along, or drag-along provisions without consuming general disposition capacity.
children.name: Joint Venture Buysell

children.definition: Disposition basket for non-core assets acquired in connection with a permitted acquisition. Allows borrowers to divest assets that do not fit their core business within a specified period post-acquisition, typically subject to net proceeds sweep.
children.name: Non Core Acquisition Assets
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition); DLS Preferred Row 67 (Security)

DISP_NON_CORE.label: Dispositions - Non-Core Assets
exactPhrases: in connection with a Permitted Acquisition
in connection with a Permitted Acquisition

children.definition: Disposition basket permitting the termination, unwinding, or close-out of hedging agreements and derivative contracts. Recognizes that terminating a swap position may result in a payment to the counterparty (a disposition of value) or receipt of a termination payment, either of which should be permitted without consuming general disposition basket capacity.
children.name: Swap Unwinding

children.definition: Disposition basket permitting the settlement, compromise, or release of legal claims, litigation rights, and other intangible assets that the borrower might otherwise be required to pursue to maximize recovery. Ensures that practical resolution of disputes through negotiated settlements is not impeded by the dispositions covenant's requirements for fair value consideration.
children.name: Settlement Compromise Claims

children.definition: Disposition basket for asset sales specifically identified and scheduled as of the closing date. Permits execution of pre-planned divestitures that were part of the transaction thesis, often listed in a schedule to the credit agreement.
children.name: Closing Date Scheduled
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios)

children.definition: Miscellaneous disposition permissions beyond the primary baskets. Per DLS Preferred row 83 alt: includes (i) de minimis amount not constituting an 'Asset Sale,' (ii) general dollar basket, (iii) sale-leaseback transactions, (iv) asset swaps, (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities. Per Learning Material: customary carve-outs include immaterial assets with dollar limits, exchange of assets for other useful assets (asset swap often unlimited in indentures), and sales of receivables in Qualified Securitization Transactions.

extraction_refs.difficulty_note: Aligned from ontology=medium vs playbook=very_hard (playbook authority for extraction complexity)

children.name: Other Disposition Baskets
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 83 alt: 5 other asset sale baskets. Learning Material: customary carve-outs including asset swaps and receivables.

definition: The negative covenant governing asset sales, transfers, licenses, leases, and other dispositions outside the ordinary course. Per Learning Material: 'Disposition means the sale, transfer, license, lease or other disposition of any property by any Person.' Creditors care because: dispositions of collateral automatically release liens, assets represent future cash flows, and dispositions change business/risk profile. Per DLS Preferred, non-ordinary course asset sales must satisfy: (i) fair market value, (ii) 75% cash consideration, (iii) proceeds to asset sale sweep, (iv) no default/EoD, and (v) annual dollar cap. Disposition proceeds feed the mandatory prepayment waterfall.

market_benchmarks.pctc_75_measurement_umm_bslr: Typically per transaction; may be cumulative in Aggressive (but include 50% cash per transaction minimum)
market_benchmarks.pctc_eod_stopper: Aggressive UMM/BSLR: payment/bktcy EoD or no stopper; Otherwise: full EoD
market_benchmarks.pctc_ratio_basket: Reject unlimited leveraged based asset sale basket
market_benchmarks.pctc_non_lp_cap: Cap dispositions to non-Loan Parties (shared with non-LP Investments and intercompany debt baskets)
market_benchmarks.source: PC Term Comparison, Asset Sales section

name: Asset Sales / Dispositions

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Designated non cash consideration basket; threshold for 75% cash No cap Other Asset Sale Basket: (i) de minimis amount that does not constitute an "Asset Sale" (ii) general dollar basket (iii) sale and leaseback transactions (iv) asset swaps (v) sales in connection with qualified receivables facilities
key_negotiation_points: Proceeds must prepay term loans via sweep
De minimis threshold for asset sale definition
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for dispositions / asset sales reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value (ii) the consideration for such sales being at least 75% cash consideration (iii) proceeds are used to prepay term loans under the asset sale sweep (iv) no default or event of default is continuing (v) assets sales not to exceed an amount in each fiscal year to be agreed

definition_source: Learning Material: 'Disposition means the sale, transfer, license, lease or other disposition of any property.' DLS Preferred row 83: 'Non-ordinary course asset sales subject to: (i) fair market value, (ii) 75% cash consideration, (iii) proceeds to asset sale sweep, (iv) no default/EoD, (v) annual cap.'
